Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing MRI- and CT-based Patient-Specific Instrumentation with Conventional Instrumentation in Total Knee Arthroplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: Ninety patients were randomised into three groups

Participants.evidence: Eligibility criteria included patients undergoing primary TKA

Intervention.evidence: MRI- and CT-based patient-specific instrumentation with conventional instrumentation

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to compare the accuracy and clinical outcomes of MRI- and CT-based patient-specific instrumentation with conventional instrumentation in total knee arthroplasty (TKA).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the accuracy of coronal and sagittal alignment, measured postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Ninety patients were randomised into three groups

Result_Outcome.evidence: MRI- and CT-based instrumentation showed higher accuracy in coronal limb axis compared to conventional instrumentation (MRI: 1.0° vs. 4.5°, p < 0.001; CT: 3.0° vs. 4.5°, p = 0.02).
